Hey guys,

I know this is going to be a controversial opinion, but I think quantum mechanics is a load of crap. I know a lot of people on this board are big fans of science and math, but I just can't get behind the idea that particles can be in multiple places at once or that they can somehow communicate with each other instantaneously. It's just too far-fetched for me.

I mean, come on, have you ever actually seen a particle in two places at once? I sure haven't. And the whole concept of quantum entanglement just doesn't make any sense to me. How can two particles that are separated by vast distances somehow be connected and know what the other is doing? It's just ridiculous.

But here's the thing: I'm not just some crank who hates science. I used to be a physics major in college, and I know enough about the subject to know that quantum mechanics doesn't add up. I've read the papers, I've done the math, and I just can't make it work in my head. I think it's time for the scientific community to admit that they got it wrong and move on to something else.

If the coin lands heads, he will have just one child total, with the woman whose bay his ship first stops by again. The diary does not record which bay his ship will first stop by again. If the coin lands tails, he will have one child by each woman (two children total), in the order of whose bays his ship first stops by again. The diary does not record the result of the coin toss.

I'll start us off with Hanson's list

1. The right star system (including organics and potentially habitable planets)

4. Complex (eukaryotic) single-cell life

I'm thinking that we should consider a living organisms' potential for energy utilization and efficiency as part of the great filter list.

The ability to utilize the necessary energy to fuel a brain to "boost overclock" a biological organism, seems kind of important.

Organisms without an "ADRENALINE BOOST" equivalent probably can't become the intelligent dominator of their planet, because true evolution happens at the margins. If a creature can't hit the "OH SHIT" button. It won't survive complex situations, in order to learn from them.

So, chemically enabled "fight or flight" is probably a filter. It might even be the greatest filter, since we can't draw on other planet's organisms' data sets just yet. (Placebo effect might even be a factor here. Being able to make yourself better, on thought alone, means you put thought into the ailment, and you biologically responded.)

But I think these are the types of possibilities that we can flesh out more, before we start to get that data.

Here's another one: language filter. While this filter is mainly anthropomorphic, the language filter is an interesting problem, I think.

It is commonly believed that language and writing are important because it allows people to spread knowledge, create ideas, conjecture new ones, and error-correct upon other ideas. This is true because 1) without language, we would not be able to communicate efficiently to our brethren that, say in the cavemen era, "This area over here is full of lions, don't go there!" or "this area is full of deer, let's hunt here," and 2) without writing, we would have a hard time accumulating knowledge because people would die and thus their knowledge dies with them.

But the problem with both language and writing, at least to humans, is that both methods of communications are linear, despite the fact that the universe is non-linear. Take for example the paragraph I wrote above: notice how it progresses in a straight-forward fashion. Or look at any complete sentence and how it flows in a linear fashion: subject, verb, and object—Mary sucks cock.

This limits our abilities to understanding the universe because the universe is not strictly linear. And because we speak and write in a linear fashion, we are thus misinterpreting the universe everyday.

One counter-argument: we interpret the universe through our sense, thus interpreting the universe nonlinearly. We soak in our environment through sight, hearing, smelling, touch, and more. This goes to show that the brain is completely capable of understanding the universe in a nonlinear fashion. But the counter-argument against the counter-argument is that our senses are easily manipulatable.

For use to pass the language filter, we need a method of understanding the universe in its nonlinear operation of itself, to "see" everything all at once, as opposed to a linear approach.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>15042770
Are you asking why we developed writing? Or are you asking if there's even a need for writing in the first place? Nonetheless, I will attempt to answer both.

Why did we develop writing? _Why_ questions are hard to answer because it would make an "answer" too overly deterministic. There are many approaches to why we developed writing. One reason: we had to accurately keep track of each other—who was indebted, who said what, who promised what, etc, "It was written and agreed upon in stone," type of scenario. Second: efficient learning—it is easier to read at 1000+ words per minute than to speak 1000+ words per minute, let alone 300. Third: messaging each other—easier to write a scroll and have someone deliver it across villages than it was to travel and speak in person. Fourth, similar to the third reason: mass distribution of knowledge—easier to print 10,000 scrolls and have each scrolls repeatedly read by others, than it was to speak to a small audience. There are plenty of other reasons, but the gist is that writing allows people to "clone" themselves and have that clone do the communicating.

As for needing writing in the first place? I think there are faster means of communications, such as sight, which acts upon the speed of light, but inherently slowed by electro-chemical processes of the brain, but is still faster than writing. Perhaps there's a way for people to communicate without directly speaking or writing to each other via internet-like telepathy. Or perhaps a flashdrive that you could plug into others. DNA for accumulation of knowledge is a rather slow process because it is almost strictly chemical. If there is an efficient way of transporting knowledge, it would be electrical.

But it is all hard to say with strong conviction.

One of the great differences between Mars and Earth involves what's going on beneath the surface. Our planet remains a tectonically and volcanically active world -- witness the current eruptions in Hawaii -- while Mars has been a cold, geologically dead place for the past three billion years. That was the thinking at least. But a new paper in Nature Astronomy challenges that accepted wisdom. Mars, it suggests, may still be geologically active today. The findings are the result of orbital photography, surface data, and computer modeling of a lowland region near the Martian equator known as Elysium Planitia -- where NASA's Mars InSight probe landed in 2018. Researchers from the University of Arizona Lunar and Planetary Laboratory analyzed recordings of Mars quakes taken by InSight and concluded that they all result from a series of subsurface fissures dubbed Cerberus Fossae, which stretch nearly 1,300 km (800 mi.) across the Martian surface. This gives rise to what are known as mantle plumes: blob-like masses of molten rock that rise to reach the base of the crust, causing quakes, faulting, and volcanic eruptions. Computer modeling of the region indicates that far from being geologically dead,

>Elysium Planitia experienced major volcanic eruptions as recently as 200 million years ago.

>>15042612
Some fields of logic are simply existing fields of logic plus a little extra.
Predicate logic takes basic propositional logic and, among other things, adds universal ("for all") and existential ("there exists") quantifiers.
Modal logic's extra is ways to express the ideas of necessity and possibility. For instance, in predicate logic, you can say "for all students s at the school, s has red hair." This may be true, but is it necessarily true, meaning did it absolutely have to be that way? Or it may be false, but is it necessarily false, meaning did it absolutely have to be that way? As you can see, necessary truth is stronger than plain old 'contingent' truth because something that's necessarily true is true in all possible worlds.

sub: Light is a particle or a wave?
com:
Hello, people say that light has properties of particles and waves. Ok, but how exactly?

We have the principle of rectilinear propagation of light as a law on Physics. Light would be a particle that propagates in a direct line pointed to all directions with origin on the source of light.

The problem is that this is impossible. Light can't be emitted in all direction in a rectilinear way. In case you stand 1 meter far away from the light source you could trace X directions. But in case you stay away 2 meters from the light source you would trace X + Y directions. And in case you stay away 3 meters away from the light source you could trace X + Y + Z directions. How can a photon be emitted in all directions rectilinearly if the amount of directions increases according to the variance of the distance? I'm being very nice saying that there are X directions when you stay 1 meter away from the light source, there are actually infinite directions even from that distance.

So light can't be a particle. It's a wave. Because waves go to all directions and they actually increase in size. A single wave gets bigger and bigger as long as it goes away from a certain origin...

It's impossible that infinite photons are emitted from the source of light in all directions since there is no energy for this.

Help me guys, I think that Einstein hasn't explained this very well.

com:
When you think about it the concepts in calculus are not that difficult. I mean, think of something like a slope. That just means how much you go up or down divided by how much you go left or right. That's pretty straight forward. And derivative simply means the value of the slope of a tangent in some part of a function. last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>15042624
I think you might be somewhat out of touch with regular children's math skills. Many of them can barely understand trigonometry at the age of 12 and think of stuff like the binomial theorem and the quadratic formula as crazy magic tricks deep into high school. Calculus might seem like a logical progression from algebra and analytic geometry once you understand limits and sums, but you really should try to consider that, for a huge chunk of the population, algebra is not intuitive at all, and analytic geometry is just odd formulas and equations that somehow represent relations between shapes and points in them.
There is a reason why Calculus is not taught as a mandatory course even at college level for people not majoring in either the natural sciences or one of the many engineering disciplines, and it's that it makes very little sense to people who don't have strong visualization and manipulation skills in algebra and geometry.
I don't think nurses, lawyers, or business managers would really need to learn calculus in order to perform their work well. Mechanics and welders clearly don't need calculus either, as seen from many examples of people who can do their work with a high degree of skill without ever having seen a single derivative formula in their lives.

sub: Winter Course in Geometric Measure Theory
com:
Hello. There is an organized reading course in Geometric Measure Theory being held from 10 Dec to 21 Jan. This will cover sections 2.1-2.6/7 of the textbook "Geometric Measure Theory" by Herbert Federer. Once this session is completed, a new schedule will be determined to continue reading deeper into the text. Problem sets and reading assignments will be posted at the beginning of each week, to be discussed the following Saturday during a group meeting.

The prerequisites for this reading course are point-set topology, linear algebra, undergraduate real analysis, and abstract algebra (standard undergraduate maths education). The textbook is self-contained with respect to measure theory, differential geometry, and algebraic topology. Therefore, you do not need to know those three subjects to participate. You are welcome to join.

name: YWPTS
com:
Artificial Acceleration of Natural Pressurized Saltwater Fusion for Practical Transmutation of Elements Using a Combination of Negative Coulomb Force Lines, Positive Coulomb Force Lines, Saltwater, an Autoclave, and Pulsed Soliton Waves

In my recent publication concerning the origin of elements heavier than zinc, I concluded that while the first thirty elements of the periodic table likely did have their origin in the center of a star, the currently prevailing theory which holds that colliding neutron stars are responsible for the formation of heavier elements is fallacious. I expounded that these heavier elements gradually accrue protons in parts of the saltwater oceans that extend below the sea floor over hundreds of millions of years and are ultimately ejected during rare undersea volcanic eruptions (the same ones associated with mass extinction events.)

If this is so, we can deduce that probability comes into play when it comes to whether any given water-associated hydrogen atom will approach an atom of a heavy element and successfully penetrate its electron cloud. I came to the conclusion that if, perchance, a moment in time existed in which the many electrons of an element like zinc were to briefly shift to a single hemisphere of the orbital space around that atom (an exceptionally rare but not implausible state,) if a hydrogen were to choose that instant to stray into proximity of the zinc (or any heavy element,) when those electrons returned to a more balanced hemispheric distribution around the atom, they would act as a guillotine, severing the hydrogen from the water. Now liberated from the water and trapped between the electron cloud and nucleus of the heavy element, the proton would be assimilated, creating a new element.

last_replies.name: YWPTS
last_replies.com:
This aspect of this hypothetical phenomenon holds in common with another of my hypotheses the feature of electrons having probabilistic alignments of position, leading to phenomena. The other phenomenon for which this clockwork-like trait of electrons comes into play is nuclear decay, which I firmly believe is triggered by perfect alignments of these electrons. If this is so, these two phenomena of nature are truly poetical as it would mean that the seeming opposites of fusion and decay both rely, in most cases, upon chance configurations of electrons.

To prove this theory and to make something useful from it, we might try to accelerate this natural process. The first and perhaps most important objective of such an accelerated pressurized saltwater fusion system is to create windows of hemispheric electron imbalance in the transmuting elements.

The best means for achieving this was first suggested by myself for the application of building improved microwave ovens. If soliton waves can be used to create hemispheric imbalances of electrons for the purpose of maximizing chances of microwave resonances, those same artificially-generated imbalances can allow protons to slip into those electron shells. When an electron slips in, the nucleus is heated. When a proton slips in, a new element is created.

Firing protons at a heavy element using a particle accelerator doesn't work for transmutative purposes because the excessive speed denies the proton the chance to gently assimilate into the existing element. This is likely the reason why this means of transmutation has not been hypothesized nor discovered to date; someone undoubtedly already tried to create new elements by violently firing protons at existing elements and failed and thus assumed that what is needed is more force. This sadly mistaken assumption has likely set reseach into this area back by decades. What is needed is less force.

last_replies.name: YWPTS
last_replies.com:
Soliton waves are walls of electrons with alternating spin directions in each of up to 90 pie-slice-like wedges making up the wall. They convey nearly all of their energy as unidirectional magnetism. Any electrons they encounter in orbit of an atom tend to be swept up by that magnetic force. That force is not quite sufficient to entirely strip away those electrons, ionizing the element, but what a soliton wave can do, in my view, is temporarily shove all of the orbital electrons to one hemisphere, leaving the opposing hemisphere open to particles that might be nudged toward its nucleus.

If we take some zinc and place it in an autoclave filled with saltwater and crank up the pressure, we can reproduce the conditions under which fusion occurs in the oceans. This process is too slow to be experimentally verified until we add a couple of additional ingredients. The primary and most important ingredient is the soliton pulser, of course, but to this we can add Coulomb Force Line-generative (both positive and negative) structures. The more the water in the autoclave is agitated on the nano-scale, the greater the chance of a hydrogen straying into proximity with the heavy element during a crucial window of opportunity. Saltwater naturally lends itself to this agitation (driving its own resistance to freezing amongst other properties.) If crystals with alignments of positive and negatively charged unit cells (alternatingly) are collocated with the element to be transmuted, we can expect that the normal agitation associated with the repulsions of the sodium chloride cubes snd the V-shaped H2O would be multiplied manifold.

The technology to build these elements of Artificially Accelerated Pressurized Saltwater Fusion already exists and requires little engineering work to combine into a revolutionary means for generation of rare earth elements.

The Future Is Made in America

last_replies.com:
>https://www.quantamagazine.org/physicists-create-a-wormhole-using-a-quantum-computer-20221130/

They're doing real cool shit. An analogy for quantum entanglement is this: imagine you amputate your arm, and ship it to China for analysis. They store it. You, in the USA, send a brain signal through your CNS to wiggle your finger in your amputated arm. The amputated arm responds and wags its finger.

The concept of a "wormhole" comes from a so-called "einstein-rosen bridge". This connects two far away regions in space via a tunnel. It'd be like walking out your house door, and instead of going into your front lawn you come out in Narnia.

They're both "action at a distance", but quantum entanglement has nothing to do with wormholes. Quantum entanglement is about information remaining coupled between two particles, despite their distance. You alter the state of one particle, and the other immediately follows tow, regardless of distance. In contrast, with a wormhole you create a portal from one region to another.

In sum, quantum entanglement requires at least two objects, whose intrinsic behaviors are coupled. A wormhole is a warping of the fabric of space that permits a single object to transport from one region to another instantly.

The only thing that the two share in common is FTL action-at-a-distance. Fuck that quanta article, the author should know better

sub: Falling magnet and the conservation of energy
com:
Ok guys, since this noon there were two questiona bugging me and I am not sure if I got it right.

1) So let´s assume there is a magnet falling down near a conducting wire. The magnet induces electic current at the wire. The current than can do some electric work.

So does the magnet slow down while going near the wire transforming part of its kinetic energy into electric or is there something more to it? I mean is part of its potential energy transformed into the electric one?

2) Does falling magnet radiate electromagnetic waves? If so, does it fall slowly than nonmagnetic objects?

Sry for being a brainlet autist.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
The simplest case is a magnet falling in a copper tube. Lots of videos on YouTube.

The magnet induced a current which then exerts a Lorentz force on the magnet. The magnet experiences a force that is linear in speed (if it doesn't move, there's not change in flux and no induced current. Faster motion means more current and more force.) A velocity dependent force will result in a terminal velocity (the v required for the magnetic drag force to equal the magnitude of the weight of the magnet).

A magnet falling near nothing would continually gain kinetic energy. One in a conducting tube would reach terminal velocity, with the energy being dissipated by the resistance in the tube. Additionally the magnet would emit radiation (probably very small amounts). The radiation would carry off some of the energy radially out and down ahead of the magnet.

Hope this helps anon. There are lots of good articles on magnets falling through copper tubes you cma check out for more info.

Laser physics phd here again.
Average day can vary a lot. I build high power lasers and we're always trying to push the limits. When I get new material to build a laser, I can spend weeks grinding in a lab testing all of its characteristics, realizing some system doesn't work, figuring out why, modifying an optical system, etc. At some point we see what would be a useful experiment and focus on that to get some results for a conference/paper etc. Tasks can vary from machining, plumbing and vacuum system assembly to developing control algorithms, splicing fiber-optic components, working with vendors to get custom optics made, getting some custom electronics working, making cad models to get components made by a workshop, or just building a particularly complex optical system. Most of us can do a little bit of everything but we're not experts in anything. Sometimes some external collaborators show up for a few days with some system they want to test with the new/upgraded laser. If the experiment works out I might spend a few weeks not doing much lab work while I write or simulate. Then either continue adding on to the current system or start over with new stuff. Luckily I build lasers from scratch and don't usually have to rely on some student's experimental laser b/c they are rarely built for long-term operation. Occasionally I jump in on other peoples experiments when they need help. Every so often an administrator asks me to put together some slides, diagrams or a video to advertise our work, or even to give a presentation or lab tour to some VIPs. Then the admin tells me to get back in the lab and make them more money. two or three times a year I travel to a conference somewhere.

com: Is there any kind of function or set of estimates for how the average sea level temperature on Earth would change as a function of greater or lesser distance from the sun? Like if we were 1% farther away would the temperature drop by 5°

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>15042140
Solar energy input per square meter (or any other unit) as a function of x, where x = distance, is 1/x^2. So, if a distance of 1 au is equal to 1 unit of energy per square unit (again, the unit doesn't matter), then increasing the distance by 0.01 au would yield 1/1.0201 = 0.98029... or a decrease of 2 %.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>15042140
Inverse square rule. 1% more distance ~2% less solar energy.
A very rough approximation for the Earth temp is the black body at equilibrium. So -2% emitted energy means -1.5ºC.
The orbital distance to the sun is very stable because of orbital resonance.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>15042171
It then stands to reason, given a linear relationship between energy input and temperature, that a decrease of 2 % should translate into a temperature that is decreased by 2 %. Considering that the average temperature of the earth is roughly 285°K, we would expect a reduction by 5.7 Kelvin yielding 279.3°K. But overall temperature of a body is actually an equistasis between energy input and radiation output, the latter being a function of T^4, which means that you're looking for a new equilibrium. Long answer short. Solar energy output increases or decreases by 1/x^2 where x = distance from the sun, but overall temperature only increases or decreases by 1/x.

[eqn] \lim_{(x,y,z) \rightarrow (2,1,-1)} 3x^2z+yx \cos(\pi (x-z))=-14 [/eqn]
In this example, the 3 variable function is
continuous everywhere in 3 dimensions, so you
evaluate each variable as normal for the answer
of -14 as your limit, regardless of path taken.
[eqn] \lim_{(x,y) \rightarrow (0,0)} {x^2y^2 \over x^4+3y^4} [/eqn]
In this one, if you set x=0 or y=0 as the path
of choice, you'll end up with a one variable
function which evaluates to zero. But, set y = x
and the limit becomes 1/4. So, the moment you
have more than one answer for the limit, it
doesn't exist.

I have a question for you all: what's the point of science? It seems to me that all it does is create more problems and cause people to doubt everything. last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
No. Why? Because the brain isn't the only feature relevant to the type of intelligence humans have. One prominent feature humans have that other animals don't is musculature and limbs structured to allow for relatively meticulous and precise tasks like constructing tools. This is why humans are physically weak for their size compared to a variety of animals of similar sizes. Their muscles are designed for things like generating speed to outrun a predator or catch prey or lifting their body weight to swing through trees as a mode of transportation without exhausting themselves. And this is without training or exercise, just a normal and expected development for those species. The design of human muscles are not conducive to feats of strength and people have to actively train for years to come close to what a chimpanzee or dog is able to do simply by waking up in the morning and being well-fed.

In summary, the brain is only one part of intelligence, the structure of the body and what behaviors and tasks an animal with such a body can perform is even more important as the brain develops hand-in-hand to enable those behaviors. Because of this, Something like Elephants or Dolphins won't develop comparable intelligence to human beings unless their bodies start to change to facilitate something like tool-making.

sub: What's happening when I'm on adderall
com:
From the perspective of one lurking sci on 4 chins
I'd like to avoid a "biological explaination", as I find this wholly unrooted in tangible existence.

When I take a high dose of adderall on occasion, say once a month or so, things feel as they ought to be.
My compulsions are essentially eliminated. There is no more compulsive behavior.
Adderall, to me, is not an "appetite suppressant", but it is eliminating compulsive consumption because 'something else' is being increased.
Rumination is eliminated. People will say something like "adhd problems with executive function" but again, this is absent existential tangibility.
My thoughts become more of a choice, and my 'intuition' is doing all the work. When I'm not on adderall, I have trended into thought-spam as a way to make sense of what it is I ought to do. When on adderall, that's not necessary. Things become a 'knowing'. I know exactly what I ought to do.
To materialise the bodies sensations into a thoughtform thus becomes a choice or a tool to assist in my lived experience. My thoughts and imagination projections become a tool to utilize on top of what it is I am actually doing. What it is I feel inclined to do, based on what I would call a heightened self-attunement.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
you're treating adhd

euphoria is unfocused, certain anons are a bit stuck in the drug war propaganda (dopamine does more than just reward signaling, and adderall does more than just flood dopamine)

it's likely an indicator that the dosage you're describing would be a reasonably therapeutic one for you. the noticeable difference is likely coming from the delay in between doses; contrary to the fearmongering ITT (and in a lot of ADHD-related threads - i blame American politics for dumping boomers all over the site), you can essentially reset your tolerance by just... taking a break from it. it's arguable that the "every day, forever" instructions that pharma loves are not the most effective way to treat ADHD with these medications, but that's another discussion.

out of curiosity, do lower doses make you sleepy as fuck? i think that's basically the strongest indicator that you're actually treating ADHD and not just experiencing mania

It's in other populations too, just common in Asians. It might not even be that. Mostly I wanted an excuse to share the video.
>The Asian flush is best known for creating a lobster-red face and neck when people drink alcohol, but the condition also results in a heightened heart rate, headache and nausea. That’s because people who turn tomato red when they drink alcohol lack activity by an enzyme called aldehyde dehydrogenase 2 (ALDH2).

Alcohol or ethanol is broken down or converted in the liver to acetaldehyde, a highly toxic compound that contributes to the hungover feeling. In most people, acetaldehyde is rapidly transformed to harmless acetate and water.

However, for some Asians, Ashkenazi Jews and others whose gene pool contains a mutant or altered form of the ALDH2 gene, the toxic acetaldehyde isn’t broken down as quickly, so it hangs around and accumulates in the liver and body — resulting in what is known as the Asian glow.
